oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thermionic Converter for Space Applications
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A thermionic converter with integral radiator intended for space applications. A thermionic converter is a simple means of generating electricity; two discs of metal are attached to each other by a ceramic divider. One of the discs is heated, creating a flow of electrons through the dividing space into the other disc. The silver discs are the converter, with the black disc acting as a radiator to shed excess heat. This converter was created by GE Research to serve on various aerospace missions.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thermionic Energy Converter Demonstration Model
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A thermionic converter setup used to demonstrate the principles behind the technology. The converter itself is at the center of the photograph. It consists of two metal discs, separated by a ceramic spacer, and mounted on a metal tripod over a bunsen burner. An alligator clip is attached to the top disc, and wires lead off to a voltage meter and an electric fan. Beneath this is a gas cylinder containing propane for the burner. The whole affair is contained in a wooden framework, and a lid for the contraption is behind and to the right of the converter. When the bunsen burner is ignited the heat would produce electricity through the thermionic converter and cause the fan to run and the meter to activate.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Beggs, James E.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. Louis Navias
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two informal portrait photographs of "Mr. Ceramics" Dr. Louis Navias. Navias was born in Grodno, Poland in 1897, raised in South Africa and educated in private English schools in Johannesburg. He came to New York City in 1914, graduated from City College of New York, and later earned his doctorate in chemistry from the University of Illinois. Navias briefly worked for the U.S. Tariff Commission and the Bausch & Lomb Optical Co. in Rochester, New York before joining the General Electric Research and Development Laboratory in 1924. Navias worked for General Electric for most of his professional career before retiring in 1962. At GE, he was a ceramics consultant contributing his knowledge in the field of industrial ceramics, porcelains, enamels, and glasses. Navias contributed to many projects including electronic tubes used in radio, television, and radar.
